content: The "National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 2000" aims to encourage private gifts for conservation efforts by the Department of the Interior and the Department of Commerce. It also involves amending the Board of Directors of the Foundation. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 2000 modify the Board of Directors to consist of 25 members representing diverse conservation viewpoints. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 2000 modify the Board of Directors to consist of 25 members representing diverse conservation viewpoints. The Foundation shall not constitute employment by, or the holding of an office of, the United States for the purpose of any Federal law. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere shall be Directors of the Foundation, appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 23 Directors who meet specific criteria, including education or experience in fish, wildlife, natural resource conservation, management, ocean, and coastal resource conservation. Continuation of terms for the 15 Directors serving on the Board is provided. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 8 new Directors to serve on the Board for a term of 6 years, with appointments to be made within 45 days of enactment. Existing Directors will continue until the expiration of their terms. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 8 new Directors to serve on the Board for terms of 2, 4, and 6 years. Vacancies on the Board are to be filled promptly within 45 days. The Secretary of the Interior appoints new Directors to serve on the Board for specific terms. Directors can serve a maximum of 2 consecutive terms, and removal requests can be made by the Executive Committee. Technical amendments are also made to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act. The Foundation Establishment Act is amended to change "Directors of the Board" to "Directors of the Foundation." Section 6 of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to include the Secretary of Commerce and the Department of Commerce. SEC. 4. RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS OF THE FOUNDATION. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to have its principal office in a county in Maryland or Virginia bordering the District of Columbia. It also grants the Foundation the authority to invest federal funds in US obligations and securities guaranteed by the United States, as well as to deposit funds provided by the Federal Government. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to use federal funds for cooperative agreements with private landowners to benefit natural resources on private land. Additionally, the Act now permits the Foundation to deposit federal funds into insured accounts and use interest or investment income for its purposes. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to use federal funds for cooperative agreements with private landowners to benefit natural resources on private land. Section 304 of Public Law 102-440 is repealed, and the Foundation must notify the Federal agency administering the program before acquiring or conveying funds. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to require the Foundation to convey acquired real property at fair market value if no objection is received from the Federal agency within 60 days. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to convey property if it is no longer valuable for conservation purposes and if the proceeds would better serve other authorized activities. Additionally, the Foundation must obtain approval for expenditures over $10,000 for printing services or capital equipment using Federal funds. SEC. 5. FUNDING. Amendment to Section 10 of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act regarding funding. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 totaling $30,000,000 to the Department of the Interior and $10,000,000 to the Department of Commerce. Funds must be provided in advance to the Foundation for matching contributions. The Foundation can receive contributions from private individuals and government agencies. Federal funds cannot be used for administrative expenses. The Foundation can also accept additional Federal funds for conservation efforts. The Foundation can use federal funds for matching contributions from private individuals and government agencies. Grant amounts cannot be used for litigation or lobbying expenses. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to limit the authority of the Foundation, stating that it cannot perform functions authorized for the National Park Foundation by Public Law 90-209.
